title: GWAS
text: Using method described gen_sim simulate genetic data, can use data visualise association studies methods prediction. artcle going cover use theory method GWAS. GWAS, stands genome-wide association studies method used , name implies, association studies. Meaning based large quantities genetic data like know places genome critical developing given sickness trait. GWAS simple terms linear regression SNP tries estimate casual effect mutation probability trait sickenes. GWAS can therefore written linear regression: \[ Y \sim \mathcal{N}(X\beta,\Sigma) \] \(Y\) denotes actual traits subjects. \(Y\) 1 subject sickness/trait zero . X genetic data, generated gen_sim() function, equal G.

title: GWAS
text: default function ?GWAS use linear regression. concept \(Y\) binary variable open door models. simple one logistic regression uses logit function activation function transform linearregression probability curve. model also implemented GWAs function can accessed setting ‘logreg = TRUE’.

title: GWAS
text: following tutorial file used generated using method described gen_sim. First load data. simulated \(10,000\times10,000\) datapoints using ‘fam=FALSE’. family structure unimportant since using trait subject. Now estimate casual effect SNP using bonferronni correction, since \(10^4\) indiviuals use \(p = 5\cdot 10^{-6}\).
code: library(genstats) library(bigsnpr) library(dplyr) genetic_data = snp_attach('genetic_data.rds') G=genetic_data$genotypes y =  genetic_data$fam %>% select('pheno_0')  beta = genetic_data$map$beta gwas_summary = GWAS(G=G, y=y[[1]], p=5e-6, logreg = FALSE, ncores=3) knitr::kable(gwas_summary[1:10,], digits = 2, align = "c")

title: GWAS
text: illustrate performance GWAS dataset \(10^5\times10^5\) datapoints used. first plot shown manhattan plot. plot illustrates well analysis differentiate casual non causal snp. Two horizontal lines drawn illustrating thresholds p-value.  can also illustrated using scatterplot. see good finding estimates extreme effects, though much difficult association analysis around middle.  see catches extreme cases. Looking powerplot see power catch less extreme cases.
code: manhattan_plot(gwas_summary, beta, thresholds = c(5e-7, 0.05)) scatter_plot(gwas_summary, beta) power_plot(gwas_summary, beta)

title: GWAS
text: Since target variable binary seem reasonable run logistic regression instead linear. plots run dataset . check perfomance use method .  scatterplot used since estimates logistic regression directly comparable actual values. noticeable difference manhattan plots, power plots however logistic regression seem weaker. methods outperformed vignette("LT-FH").
code: gwaslog_summary = GWAS(G=G, y=y[[1]], p=0.05e-7, logreg = TRUE, ncores=3) knitr::kable(gwaslog_summary[1:10,], digits = 2, align = "c") manhattan_plot(gwaslog_summary, beta, thresholds = c(5e-7, 0.05)) power_plot(gwas_summary, beta)

title: LT-FH
text: following tutorial file used generated using method described ‘vignette(“Simulation”)’. First load data. simulated \(1e^4\times1e^4\) data points using two siblings. following 100 SNPs casual effect. data used show case method illustrate package can used. methods used actual statistical analysis recommend simulating \(1e^5\times1e^5\) data points 500-1000 casual SNPs. practical reasons apple show case analysis. included pictures illustrate results \(1e^5\times1e^5\) data. now run LT-FH can see get estimates subjects genetic liabilities new column. estimated expected genetic liability match actual values l_g_0 can show plotting estimated vs true. plot done subject parent get clear plot.  looks great! seems y=x line runs mean configuration. estimated genetic liabilities can now used wanted. using target vector linear regression order estimate causal effect SNP see vignette("GWAS"). table see result association analysis, can see SNPs estimated casual. using Bonferroni correction lower amount false positive causal SNP. since \(10^4\) individuals use \(p==5e\cdot 10^{-6}\).
code: # The rds file containing simulated data is loaded genetic_data = snp_attach('genetic_data.rds')  # We save the genotypes and beta for later use G = genetic_data$genotypes beta = genetic_data$map$beta LTFH_est = LTFH(data = genetic_data, n_sib = 2) LTFH_est[1:10,] %>% select(contains(c("0", "pheno"))) %>%  knitr::kable(., digits = 2, align = "c") genetic_data_nosib = genetic_data  genetic_data_nosib$fam <- genetic_data$fam %>% select(-contains(c("s4", "s3")))  LTFH_est0 = LTFH(data = genetic_data_nosib, n_sib = 0)    LTFH_plot(LTFH_est0) LTFH_summary = GWAS(G = G, y = LTFH_est$l_g_0, p = 5e-6, logreg = FALSE, ncores = 3) knitr::kable(LTFH_summary[1:10,], digite = 2, align = "c")

title: LT-FH
text: give results association analysis data set \(10^5\times10^5\) data points. process getting result shown used p-value Bonferroni correction \(p=5\cdot 10^{-7}\). first plot shown Manhattan plot. plot illustrates well analysis differentiate casual non causal SNP. Two horisontal lines drawn illustrating thresholds p-value. can see choosing use conservative method Bonferroni correction describe data better. Comparing result GWAS without using estimated liabilities see LTFH clearly performs better.  can also illustrated using scatter plot. see good finding estimates extreme effects, though much difficult association analysis around middle. method much performs normal vignette("GWAS").  last include power plot show case able estimate smaller causal effects. simply power test !
code: manhattan_plot(gwas_summary = LTFH_summary, beta = beta, thresholds = c(5e-7, 0.05)) scatter_plot(gwas_summary = LTFH_summary, beta = beta) power_plot(gwas_summary = LTFH_summary, beta = beta)

what: Note on LT-FH on real world data
title: LT-FH
text: performance improvement , simulated data, expected since know fact right assumptions data made. real world data used certainty assumptions hold expect LTFH perform worse shown , therefore relevant update covariance matrix suit real world data beta. E. g. adding kind correlation parent’s child’s environmental liability. spite Hujoel et al.(2020) show LTFH outperforms standard GWAS real world data well.

title: Prediction
text: prediction use training set test set. following section going show method uses LT-FH estimates target vectors. Using PRS want find threshold p-value describes data best. therefore using cross validation. following function outputs PRS estimates validation set fold training data. use scores evaluate threshold. following plot evaluated \(10^5\times10^3\) data.    Looking plot find optimal threshold p-value around 3. Next like know value PRS decision boundary expect best result. considering may false negatives experience. much important amount false positives low. Like GWAS LT-FH prefer much conservative prediction. using cross validation following output \(10^5\times10^3\) matrix.  choose boundary around 0.25. now ready create prediction.
code: # Loading our train and test set train_set = snp_attach("genetic_data.rds") test_set = snp_attach("genetic_data_test.rds")  # We save the genotypes and target vector G = train_set$genotypes est <- LTFH(data = train_set, n_sib = 2) %>% select(., contains("est")) y_ltfh = est[[1]] prs = PRS_cross(train_data = train_set, y = y_ltfh, cross_folds = 4) prs_plot(PRS = prs, train_set, 'AUC') prs_plot(PRS = prs, train_set, 'MSE') prs_plot(PRS = prs, train_set, 'R2') decision_cross(train_data = train_set, y = y_ltfh, cross_folds = 4, bounds=seq(0.2, 0.3, 0.01), thr = 3)

title: Prediction
text: Using can create model. using linear regression, since using LT-FH estimates target vector.  creating predictions know use value found decision boundary following result.
code: ltfh_model = pred_model(train_data = train_set, y = y_ltfh, thr = 3, LogReg = FALSE) pred = prediction(test_data = test_set, gwas = ltfh_model, thr = 3) preds = (pred > 0.25)-0 confusion_matrix = as_tibble(table('Predicted' = preds[,1], 'Actual'= test_set$fam$pheno_0))  confusion_matrix %>%    ggplot(aes(x = Predicted, y = Actual)) +   geom_tile(aes(fill = n), show.legend = FALSE) +   geom_text(aes(label = sprintf("%1.0f", n)), vjust = 1) +   scale_fill_gradient(high = "firebrick", low = 'dodgerblue3', trans='pseudo_log')

title: Prediction
text: section explain process behind result. can expect able predict genetic liability. subject low genetic liability, high environmental liability can course catch PRS. therefore going plot PRS genetic liability.  can see plot two values correlated. therefore reasonable add PRS controlling variable prediction studies performed. can also plot PRS test set.  expected boundary cases non cases bit less clear, still see high correlation.

title: Simulating data
text: package offers different methods simulating data. First going show simply get genotypes N subjects genetic full liabilities. using small scale test, recommend data used actual statistic analysis least \(10^4\times10^4\) data points simulated. Now exist rds file working directory data, load. Looking data see file contains list. can find genotypes (G), information SNP (map) liabilities (fam). Genotypes Map Fam effect causal snip distribution \(\mathcal{N}\left( 0, \frac{h^2}{c}\right)\) minor allele distribution \(unif(0.01, 0.49)\). Using function dist_check() can see distribution full liabilities expected, standard normal. using small test set expect mean variance close 0 1.  can see mean variance differ lot 0 1, stated small data set larger simulation distribution come lot closer expected values, qqplot however resembles normal distribution. now possible perform GWAS association analysis use genotypes prediction.
code: gen_sim('simple_sim_example', N=1000, M=1000, C=50, block_size = 100, fam=FALSE) simple_data = snp_attach('simple_sim_example.rds') class(simple_data) #> [1] "list" d1 = simple_data$genotypes[1:10,1:5] d2 = simple_data$map[1:10,] d3 = simple_data$fam[1:10,]  knitr::kables(   list(knitr::kable(d1, col.names = c(1,2,3,4,5), caption = 'Genotypes'),         knitr::kable(d2, align = "c", digits = 3, caption = 'Map'),         knitr::kable(d3, align = "c", digits = 2, caption = 'Fam'))) dist_check(simple_data) #>     mean_l0 variance_l0  #>   -0.552989    1.634673

title: Simulating data
text: Simulation family history similar simulating without. see bit family history, values family member subject. can check distribution full liability using function .  Now larger data set simulated mean variance lot closer expected values liabilities qqplots liability clearly resembles normal distribution. Now data ready analysed using LTFH used predictive analysis.
code: gen_sim('genetic_data', N=10000, M=10000, C=100, block_size = 1000, n_sib=2) family_data = snp_attach('genetic_data.rds') knitr::kable(family_data$fam[1:10,2:16], align = "c", digits = 2) dist_check(family_data) #>     mean_l0 variance_l0  #> 0.007328894 0.944272064  #>     mean_l1 variance_l1  #> 0.005552209 1.046033033  #>     mean_l2 variance_l2  #>  0.01255945  1.01357212  #>     mean_l3 variance_l3  #> -0.02114777  0.96889338  #>     mean_l4 variance_l4  #>  -0.0031872   0.9506856
